albumData.title: 150905 Fabricating window pane mutton hangers from floppy disk parts

media.description: The window panes (muttons) in our front door occasionally fall out.  Sometimes they break and I have to glue them.  They are held in by little metal clips, but they get bent and require readjustment.  After many years of misuse by window cleaners and adjustment, the metal fatigued and the first one has failed.  I can't find them online, so what can I do... I have to make a replacement!
media.title: 20150905_121848.jpg

media.description: Here is a surviving metal clip in the windowpane.
media.title: 20150905_111340.jpg

media.description:
The maker of the window 
(turned out to be inconsequential)

You can see the windowpanes sitting on the floor in the background.
media.title: 20150905_111302.jpg

media.description:
The broken clip, and a clue!
Unfortunately the patent is easy to find, 
replacement parts were not.
media.title: 20150905_112101.jpg

media.description: At first I thought the mounting brackets from these pager motors would be good steel to work with.
media.title: 20150905_114838.jpg

media.description: The original brackets are .28mm thick
media.title: 20150905_114926.jpg

media.description:
The pager motor mounts are .31mm thick.
It might not seem like much but they are 10% thicker and besides they are preformed and cut in a pattern that would be awkward to work around, so the hunt continues for another source of thin workable metal...
media.title: 20150905_114959.jpg

media.description:
Ah Ha!
I have boxes of old floppies inherited from my father for merely mentioning that I heard the disks are infrared passive filters.
Each one contains a plastic jacket, floppy disk, with steel hub, thin metal door, and spring.
media.title: 20150905_115136.jpg

media.description: At .27mm, the door looks just about right, though I had my eye on the hub too.
media.title: 20150905_115228.jpg

media.description: Metalworking with Fiskars
media.title: 20150905_115319.jpg

media.description: Forming the lip with my grandfathers flat jewler's pliers
media.title: 20150905_115523.jpg

media.description: Marking the portion to cut away to make the holder the same depth as the original.  I chose to make it slightly wider to compensate for the metal not being as stiff and springy as the original.
media.title: 20150905_115911.jpg

media.description:
Yay!
I'm done!
media.title: 20150905_120024.jpg

media.description:
Boo!
I made the clip backwards, I have to start over...
media.title: 20150905_120150.jpg

media.description:
I thought I might just turn the grabber around by flattening and reversing all the folds.
Truth is, I knew better, I knew metal fatigue would cause it to fall apart, and frankly I'm glad it failed on the desk and not in the front door.
media.title: 20150905_120246.jpg

media.description: Marking another piece of metal for forming.
media.title: 20150905_120616.jpg

media.description: Traced point outline to match depth of original again.
media.title: 20150905_120824.jpg

media.description:
Broken piece, new piece and remaining floppy door metal.
I can do this all day!
media.title: 20150905_120942.jpg

media.description: Window panes back in door.
media.title: 20150905_121445.jpg

media.description: My new clip at work.
media.title: 20150905_121433.jpg

media.description: An original clip for comparison.
media.title: 20150905_121452.jpg
